prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 HCN / HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observations toward AA Tau of the J = 3-2 transitions of HCN and HCO+, along with other minor transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The sensitivity requested is based on the expected image requirements of HCN and HCO+ towards the edges of the disk (>200 AU), where we need to be able to detect signals on the order of 10mJy/beam in order to compare the distributions of the different molecules. These flux levels come from simulations (Figure 2), calibrated with observations from Oberg et al. 2010. For a 5 sigma detection we therefore request a rms of 2 mJy per 1 km/s, which will provide a minimum of 4-5 (binned) resolution elements with appropriate SNR across the lines.

When considering both intrinsic line strengths and low excitation temperatures of organics in disks, the 3-2 transition of these molecules becomes ideal for maximum signal strength. Band 6 is therefore optimal for imaging HCN and HCO+, which will trace the warm molecular layer and molecular layer/midplane boundaries. The primary frequency windows are selected to cover the most intense hyperfine component of the HCN 3-2 line around 265.881 GHz, and the HCO+ 3-2 line at 267.552 GHz. An additional window is placed on the HC18O+ 3-2 line as a secondary target. The requested frequency resolution for these lines corresponds to ~0.14 km/s, which will enable detailed velocity structure modeling (~30 channels across the line).
We additionally place a continuum band to enable self-calibration.

To resolve the differences in the HCN and HCO+ vertical profiles in the outer disk, we require a spatial resolution of 30 AU (see Figures 1-2), corresponding to 0.2". We used the Cycle 2 configuration 7 (this proposal is a resubmission of an accepted Cycle 2 proposal), which results in synthesized beam of ~0.2", to simulate observations with CASA Simobserve() and confirm that the structure is able to be distinguished at this resolution (see Figure 2). No extended structure is present in the source larger than 2.5". Our simulations resulted in all flux from the skymodels being recovered, and therefore no ACA is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 CO/CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 observations toward AA Tau of the J = 3-2 transitions of CO isotopologues and CN, along with other minor transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The sensitivity requested is based on the expected image requirements of CN and CO isotopologues towards the edges of the disk (>200 AU), where we need to be able to detect signals of 15mJy/beam in order to compare the distributions of the different molecules. The flux levels come from simulations calibrated with observations from Oberg et al. 2010. For a 5 sigma detection we therefore request a rms of 3 mJy per 1 km/s, which will provide a minimum of 4-5 (binned) resolution elements with appropriate SNR across the lines.

When considering both intrinsic line strengths and low excitation temperatures of organics in disks, the 3-2 transition of these molecules becomes ideal for maximum signal strength. Band 7 is therefore optimal for imaging CO and CN, which will trace the the warm molecular layer and the ionizing outer layers of the disk. The primary frequency windows are selected to cover the strongest hyperfine components of the CN 3-2 line around 340 GHz, and the 13CO and C18O 3-2 lines at 330.59 GHz and 329.33 GHz. The CO isotopologues are chosen as CO is most likely optically thick towards the source and the CO isotopologues fit in a more convenient correlator setup with CN. Additional windows used for secondary targets are placed on the HC18O+ 4-3 line at 340.63 GHz and a continuum measurement at 342 GHz. The requested frequency resolution for the high-priority lines corresponds to ~0.13 km/s, which will enable detailed velocity structure modeling (~30 channels across the line).

To resolve the differences in the CN and CO isotopologue lines vertical profiles in the outer disk, we require a spatial resolution of 30 AU (see Figures 1-2), corresponding to 0.2". We used the Cycle 2 configuration 6 (this proposal is a resubmission of an accepted Cycle 2 proposal), which results in synthesized beam of ~0.2", to simulate observations with CASA Simobserve() and confirm that the structure is able to be distinguished at this resolution (see Figure 2). No extended structure is present in the source larger than 2.5". Our simulations resulted in all flux from the skymodels being recovered, and therefore no ACA is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 N2H+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 observations toward AA Tau of the J = 3-2 transition of N2H+, along with other minor transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The sensitivity requested is based on the expected image requirements of N2H+ towards the edges of the disk (>200 AU), where we need to be able to detect signals of approximately 12mJy/beam in order to compare the distributions of the different molecules (see Figures 1-2). These flux levels from simulations, calibrated with observations from Oberg et al. 2010. Given that the N2H+ distribution is expected to be concentrated toward the midplane and also taking into account the high calibration/overhead requirements of band 7, a 4 sigma detection of N2H+ toward the edge of the midplane will be sufficient to achieve our science goals. For a 4 sigma detection we therefore request a rms of 3 mJy per 1 km/s, which will provide a minimum of 4-5 (binned) resolution elements with appropriate SNR across the line.

When considering both intrinsic line strengths and low excitation temperatures of organics in disks, the 3-2 transition of these molecules becomes ideal for maximum signal strength. Band 7 is therefore optimal for imaging N2H+, which will trace the cold midplane of the disk. The primary frequency window is selected to cover the N2H+ 3-2 line around 279.51 GHz. Four additional windows in a second baseband at ~290GHz around are placed on the 4-3 line of DCN, two high line strength transitions of CH3OH, and the 4(04)-3(03) transition of H2CO as secondary targets. These molecules are all predicted to be present in abundance toward protoplanetary disks, and the high sensitivity of ALMA provides a compelling opportunity for detection. A final window in a third baseband is placed on the 4-3 transition of DCO+ at 288.14GHz. The requested frequency resolution corresponds to ~0.15 km/s, which will enable both detailed velocity structure modeling of N2H+ (~25 channels across the line), as well as channel binning for potential detections of the secondary target molecules.
We add a continuum measurement to enable self-calibration.

To image the N2H+ line at a level where it is clear that the distribution is toward the midplane, rather than extended vertically, we require a spatial resolution of 30 AU (see Figures 1-2), corresponding to 0.2". We used the Cycle 2 configuration 6 (this proposal is a resubmission of an accepted Cycle 2 proposal), which results in synthesized beam of ~0.2", to simulate observations with CASA Simobserve() and confirm that the structure is able to be distinguished at this resolution (see Figure 2). No extended structure is present in the source larger than 2.5". Our simulations resulted in all flux from the skymodels being recovered, and therefore no ACA is required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protoplanetary disks are proposed to be characterized by radial and vertical gradients in density, temperature, ionization, radiation flux and chemistry. Spatially resolved ALMA observations of molecular lines have confirmed the presence of radial temperature and chemical structures in disks, while constraints on the vertical structures remain scarce. We propose to exploit the exceptional spatial resolution of ALMA and the viewing geometry of the edge-on disk AA Tau to obtain the first direct imaging constraints on the vertical chemical and ionization structure in a protoplanetary disk. We will target molecules and ions proposed to trace the disk atmosphere, warm molecular layer and cold midplane to benchmark our understanding of how disk structures and chemistry depend on disk height.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
